item.description: Quartz runs on top ofÂ HugoÂ so all notes are written inÂ Markdown and can be edited through any editor.

item.title: How to Contribute to the Glossary
item.description: [!info] General Infos If you want to know more general how this glossary works, see General Info with a description of folder structure, how to create a link, etc.

item.title: About this Glossary
item.description: The Airbyte Glossary is built on top of the Digital Garden analogy. Instead of aligning all glossary terms in a single level, the digital garden approach lets you go inwards.

item.title: Airbyte Catalog
item.description: [!info] Info This is only relevant for individuals who want to create a connector. This refers to how you define the data that you can retrieve from a Source.

item.title: Airbyte CDK
item.description: The Airbyte CDK (Connector Development Kit) allows you to create connectors for Sources or Destinations. If your source or destination doesn’t exist, you can use the CDK to make the building process a lot easier.

item.title: Airbyte Normalization
item.description: NormalizationÂ is the process of structuring data from the source into a format appropriate for consumption in the destination. For example, when writing data from a nested, dynamically typed source like a JSON API to a relational destination like Postgres,Â normalizationÂ is the process that un-nests JSON from the source into a relational table format that uses the appropriate column types in the destination.

item.title: Airbyte Specification
item.description: [!info] Info This is only relevant for individuals who want to create a connector. This refers to the functions that a Source or Destination must implement to successfully retrieve data and load it, respectively.

item.title: Data Engineering Concepts
item.description: Some core concepts we are going to explore: Data Warehouse vs Data Lake vs Data Lakehouse Storage Layer vs Data Lake File Format vs Data Lake Table Format Data Catalog Modern Data Stack vs Open Data Stack Data Engineering Lifecycle ELT vs ETL vs EtLT Functional Data Engineering vs Software-Defined Assets Metrics Layer vs Semantic Warehouse vs Data Virtualization Metrics, Key Performance Indicator (KPI) Push-Downs vs Rollup Data Modeling vs Dimensional Modeling Data Contract OLAP vs OLTP MapReduce and Apache Hadoop Declarative vs Imperative Notebooks See also What is Data Engineering.

item.title: Data Engineering Guides
item.description: Some Data Engineering Guides that will help you learn data engineering: Data Quality How to handle [[term/data quality]] issues by detecting, understanding, fixing, and reduce Data Lake / Lakehouse Guide The what & why of a Data Lake Differences between Lakehouse & Data Warehouse Components of a data lake Storage Layer Data Lake File Format Data Lake Table Format with Apache Parquet, Apache Iceberg, and Apache Hudi Trends in the market We answer questions such as: How to build an open-source data lake offloading data for analytics?

item.title: ETL and ELT with Airbyte
item.description: ELT and ETL specific to Airbyte mean: Extract: Retrieve data from aÂ source, which can be an application, database, or anything really.

item.title: ETL vs. ELT
item.description: ETLÂ (Extract, Transform, and Load) and ELT (Extract, Load, and Transform) are two paradigms for moving data from one system to another.

item.title: Glossary of Terms (Airbyte Specific)
item.description: This is the start of the Glossary relevant for Airbyte specific, which are related to docs.airbyte.com or when using Airbyte.

item.title: Maxime Beauchemin
item.description: Creator of [[Apache Airflow]] and Apache Superset. Started as Business Intelligence Engineer and is working now at [[Preset]] (Superset as a Service).

item.title: Other Data Glossaries
item.description: Other helpful data glossaries: Seconda Glossary Prisma’s Data Guide Reddit Data Engineering Wiki

item.title: Partial Success
item.description: AÂ Partial SuccessÂ indicates that some records were successfully committed to the destination during a sync, even when the overall sync status was reported as a failure.

item.title: Programming Languages?
item.description: 2022 marks JavaScriptâ€™s tenth year in a row as the most commonly used programming language according to Stack Overflow Developer Survey 2022.

item.title: Raw Tables
item.description: Airbyte spits out tables with the prefixÂ _airbyte_raw_. This is your replicated data, but the prefix indicates that it’s not normalized.

item.title: Temporal
item.description: [!info] Info This is only relevant for individuals who want to learn about or contribute to our underlying platform.

item.title: The Data Hierarchy of Needs
item.description: The data hierarchy of needs in this image is inspired byÂ Grouparoo’s blog post: More on Reverse ETL Explained.

item.title: What are ACID Transactions?
item.description: AnÂ ACID transactionÂ secures that either all changes are successfully committed or rollbacked. It makes sure you never end in an inconsistent state.

item.title: What are Airbyte Streams?
item.description: In order to understandÂ AirbyteStreams, letâ€™s first talk about theÂ AirbyteCatalog. AnÂ AirbyteCatalogÂ describes the structure of data in a data source.

item.title: What are Business Intelligence Tools?
item.description: Business Intelligence tools visualizing your data across the organizations. See a curated list of tools including the referenced image below on Catalog of BI tools.

item.title: What are Dimensions?
item.description: Dimensions are the categorical buckets that can be used to segment, filter, or groupâ€”such as sales amount region, city, product, color, and distribution channel.

item.title: What are Notebooks?
item.description: Data notebooks popularized by Jupyter notebooks are the centralized IDE inside a browser for doing collaborative work. Notebooks that are popularized and in heavy use today.

item.title: What is a CDP (Customer Data Platform)?
item.description: A customer Data Platform (CDP) is a system that collects large quantities of customer data (i.e. information about your customers) from a variety of channels and devices, helping to make this data more accessible to the people who need it.

item.title: What is a CTE (Common Table Expression)?
item.description: A Common Table Expression (CTE) is a temporary named result set that you can reference within a SELECT, INSERT, UPDATE, or DELETE statement.

item.title: What is a Cursor?
item.description: At a conceptual level, a cursor is a tracker that is used during incremental synchronization to ensure that only newly updated or inserted records are sent from a data source to a destination in any given synchronization iteration.

item.title: What is a Data Asset?
item.description: A data asset is typically a database table, a machine learning model, or a report. A persistent object that captures some understanding of the world.

item.title: What is a Data Catalog?
item.description: A Data CatalogÂ is a centralized store where all metadata data about your data is made searchable. Think about a Google Search for your internal Metadata.

item.title: What is a Data Contract?
item.description: Data Contracts are API-like agreements between software/data engineers who own services and data consumers that understand how the business works. The goal is to generate well-modeled, high-quality, trusted, real-time data.

item.title: What is a Data Lake File Format?
item.description: Data lake file formats are the new CSVs on the cloud. They are more column-oriented and compress large files with added features.

item.title: What is a Data Lake Table Format?
item.description: Data lake table formats are very attractive as they are databases onÂ Data Lake. Same as a table, oneÂ data lake table format bundles distributed files into one table that is otherwise hard to manage.

item.title: What is a Data Lake Transaction Log?
item.description: The transaction log is the ordered record of every transaction, with a configurable duration that can optionally be set to retain all transactions (i.

item.title: What is a Data Lake?
item.description: A Data Lake is a storage system with vast amounts of unstructured and structured data, stored as-is, without a specific purpose in mind, that can be built on multiple technologies such as Hadoop, NoSQL, Amazon Simple Storage Service, a relational database, or various combinations and different formats (e.

item.title: What is a Data Lakehouse?
item.description: A Data Lakehouse open data management architecture that combines the flexibility, cost-efficiency, and scale ofÂ Data LakeÂ with the data management and ACID transactions ofÂ Data WarehouseÂ with Data Lake Table FormatsÂ ( Delta Lake, Apache Iceberg & Apache Hudi) that enable Business IntelligenceÂ (BI) and Machine LearningÂ (ML) on all data.

item.title: What is a Data Orchestrator?
item.description: A Data OrchestratorÂ models dependencies between different tasks inÂ complex heterogeneous cloud environmentsÂ end-to-end. It handles integrations with legacy systems, new cloud-based tools, and your data lakes and data warehouses.

item.title: What is a Data Product?
item.description: DJ Patil, the former Chief Data Scientist of the United States, defined a data product as “a product that facilitates an end goal through data.

item.title: What is a Data Swamp?
item.description: Data swamps start to arise when there is a lack of responsibilities, data ownership, availability, and data governance. It’s when aÂ Data LakeÂ is unmanaged or unable to provide value.

item.title: What is a Data Warehouse?
item.description: A Data Warehouse, in short DWH, also known as anÂ Enterprise Data WarehouseÂ (EDW), is the traditional way of collecting data as we doÂ since 30+ years.

item.title: What is a Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG)?
item.description: DAG stands for Directed Acyclic Graph. A DAG is a graph where information must travel along with a finite set of nodes connected by vertices.

item.title: What is a Jinja Template?
item.description: Jinja is a fast, expressive, extensible templating engine. Special placeholders in the template allow writing code similar to Python syntax. Then the template is passed data to render the final document.

item.title: What is a Lambda Architecture?
item.description: Lambda architectureÂ is aÂ data-processingÂ architecture designed to handle massive quantities of data by taking advantage of bothÂ batchÂ andÂ stream-processingÂ methods.

item.title: What is a Metric?
item.description: A Metric, also called KPI or (calculated) measure, are terms that serve as the building blocks for how business performance is both measured and defined, as knowledge of how to define an organization’s KPIs.

item.title: What is a Metrics Layer?
item.description: [!info] Similarities to a Semantic Layer The metrics layer is one component of a Semantic Layer. A limited metrics layer is usually built into a BI tool, translating its metrics to only that BI tool.

item.title: What is a Push-Down?
item.description: Query pushdown aims to execute as much work as possible in the source databases. Push-downs or query pushdowns push transformation logic to the source database.

item.title: What is a Rollup?
item.description: Rollup isÂ a form of summarization or pre-aggregation. Rolling up data can dramatically reduce the size of data to be stored and reduce row counts by potential orders of magnitude.

item.title: What is a Semantic Layer
item.description: A semantic layer (sometimes also called Headless BI) calculates complex business metrics at query time. It sits between your data sources/transformation layer and your analytics tools.

item.title: What is a Semantic Warehouse
item.description: It incorporates best practices espoused byÂ Bill InmonÂ for robust, scalable warehouse design built for the cloud as an abstraction of the [[Modern Data Stack]] with [[term/ata modeling]] at its core.

item.title: What is a Soft Delete?
item.description: In order to propagate records that have been deleted when usingÂ Incremental SynchronizationÂ modes, records in a database may include a field that indicates that a record should be treated as if it has been removed.

item.title: What is a Software-Defined Asset?
item.description: The software-defined asset was first introduced by Dagster with the following definition: A new, declarative approach to managing data and orchestrating its maintenance.

item.title: What is a Storage Layer / Object Store?
item.description: A storage layer or object storage are services from the three big cloud providers, AWS S3, Azure Blob Storage, and Google Cloud Storage.

item.title: What is a sync run?
item.description: Airbyte replication can be thought of as a loop which periodically requests records from a data source and sends them to a destination.

item.title: What is an In-Memory Format?
item.description: In-memory formats are optimized to: hit fast instruction sets be cache friendly be parallelizable Formats: Apache Arrow Apache Spark [[DataFrames]] NumPy Pandas The opposed to in-memory formats are Data Lake File Formats which save space, be cross-language and serve as long-term storage.

item.title: What is Analytics?
item.description: Analytics is the systematic computational analysis of [[data]] or statistics. It is used for the discovery, interpretation, and communication of meaningful patterns in data.

item.title: What is Apache Arrow?
item.description: Apache Arrow is a development platform for in-memory analytics. It contains a set of technologies that enable big data systems to process and move data fast.

item.title: What is Apache Avro?
item.description: Avro is an open-source data serialization system that helps with data exchange between systems, programming languages, and processing frameworks. Avro helps define a binary format for your data, as well as map it to the programming language of your choice.

item.title: What is Apache Hadoop?
item.description: Apache Hadoop is a collection of open-source software utilities that facilitates using a network of many computers to solve problems involving massive amounts of data and computation.

item.title: What is Apache Hive?
item.description: Apache Hive is aÂ Data WarehouseÂ software project built on top ofÂ Apache HadoopÂ for providing data queries and analysis. Hive gives an SQL-like interface to query data stored in various databases and file systems that integrate with Hadoop.

item.title: What is Apache Hudi?
item.description: Apache Hudi is aÂ Data Lake Table FormatÂ and was originally developed at Uber in 2016 (code-named and pronounced “Hoodie”), open-sourced end of 2016 ( first commitÂ in 2016-12-16), and submitted to the Apache Incubator in January 2019.

item.title: What is Apache Iceberg?
item.description: Apache Iceberg is aÂ Data Lake Table FormatÂ and wasÂ initially developedÂ at Netflix to solve long-standing issues using huge, petabyte-scale tables.

item.title: What is Apache Parquet?
item.description: Apache Parquet is a free and open-source column-orientedÂ Data Lake File FormatÂ in the Apache Hadoop ecosystem. It is similar to RCFile andÂ ORC, the other columnar-storage file formats in Hadoop, and is compatible with most of the data processing frameworks around Hadoop.

item.title: What is Apache Spark?
item.description: Apache Sparkâ„¢Â is an open-source multi-language engine for executing Data Engineering and Machine Learning on single-node machines or clusters. It’s optimized for large-scale data processing.

item.title: What is Behavioral Data?
item.description: Behavioral data are a result of users performing actions or events while interacting with a product and are therefore also referred to as event data or product-usage data.

item.title: What is Bus Matrix?
item.description: A Bus Matrix was traditionally used in OLAP cubes such as Microsoft SSAS and co. They let you visually see what [[Measure]] can be queried with which dimensions.

item.title: What is Business Intelligence?
item.description: Business intelligence (BI) leverages software and services to transform data into actionable insights that inform an organizationâ€™s business decisions. The new term is Data Engineering.

item.title: What is Dagster?
item.description: Dagster is a data orchestrator focusing on data-aware scheduling that supports the whole development lifecycle, with integrated lineage and observability, a declarative programming model, and best-in-class testability.

item.title: What is Data Engineering?
item.description: The definition from theÂ Fundamentals of Data Engineering, as itâ€™s one of the most recent and complete: Data engineering is the development, implementation, and maintenance of systems and processes that take in raw data and produce high-quality, consistent information that supports downstream use cases, such as analysis and machine learning.

item.title: What is data enrichment
item.description: Data enrichment is a kind of data transformation which adds additional information to the data in order to makes new kinds of queries possible and/or more efficient.

item.title: What is Data Federation
item.description: Data Federation is a virtual layer very similar to Data Virtualization. The slight difference is that data federations include federated query engines such as [[Trino]], [[Presto]], [[Spark]], and alike.

item.title: What is Data Governance?
item.description: Data governanceÂ is a collection of processes, roles, policies, standards, and metrics that ensure the effective and efficient use of information in enabling an organization to achieve its goals.

item.title: What is Data Lineage?
item.description: Data lineage uncovers the life cycle of data. It aims to show the complete data flow from start to finish. Data lineage is the process of understanding, recording, and visualizing data as it flows from data sources to consumption.

item.title: What is Data Mesh?
item.description: TheÂ Data Mesh PaperÂ tries to eliminate silos between data teams, ensuring that the experience and knowledge about data are shared among all data consumers in the company.

item.title: What is Data Modeling?
item.description: Data modeling in software engineering is the process of creating a data model for an information system by applying certain formal techniques.

item.title: What is Data Observability?
item.description: Data observability, also known as monitoring, continuously collects metrics about your data. You can collect data about the number of rows, columns, and properties for each dataset.

item.title: What is Data Quality?
item.description: Data quality is the process of ensuring data meets expectations. There are three main ways to detect a data quality issue:Â A business user reports an issue.

item.title: What is data transformation?
item.description: Data transformation is the process of converting data from one format into a different format. Reasons for doing this could be to optimize the data for a different use case than it was originally intended for, or to meet the requirements for storing data in a different system.

item.title: What is Data Virtualization?
item.description: Data Virtualization helps you when you have many source systems from different technologies, but all of them are rather fast in response time, and if you don’t run a lot of operational applications.

item.title: What is DataOps?
item.description: Similar to howÂ DevOpsÂ changed the way software is developed, DataOps is changing the way data products are created. With DataOps, data engineers and data scientists can work together, bringing a level of collaboration and communication, with a common goal of producing valuable insight for the business.

item.title: What is declarative?
item.description: AÂ declarativeÂ data pipeline does not tell the order it needs to be executed but instead allows each step/task to find the best time and way to run.

item.title: What is Delta Lake?
item.description: Delta Lake is an open-sourceÂ Data Lake Table FormatÂ project created by Databricks and kindly open-sourced with itsÂ first public GitHub CommitÂ on 2019-04-22.

item.title: What is DevOps?
item.description: DevOpsÂ is a combination of software developers (dev) and operations (ops). It is defined as a software engineering methodology that aims to integrate the work of software development and software operations teams by facilitating a culture of collaboration and shared responsibility.

item.title: What is Dimensional Modeling?
item.description: Dimensional modeling (DM) is part of the Business Dimensional Lifecycle methodology developed by [[Ralph Kimball]], which includes a set of methods, techniques, and concepts for use in Data Warehouse design.

item.title: What is DuckDB?
item.description: DuckDB is an in-process SQL OLAP database management system. It has strong support for SQL. DuckDB is borrowing the SQLite shell implementation.

item.title: What is ELT?
item.description: ELT (Extract, Load, and Transform) is a data integration approach that extracts (E) data from a source system, and loads (L) raw data into a destination system before it transforms (T) the data.

item.title: What is ETL?
item.description: ETL (Extract, Transform, and Load) is a paradigm for moving data from one system to another. It involves reading data (Extract) from one system, modifying the data (Transform), and then sending it (Load) to a destination system.

item.title: What is EtLT?
item.description: EtLT refers to Extract, â€œtweakâ€, Load, Transform, and can be thought of an extension to the ELT approach to data integration.

item.title: What is Full Refresh Synchronization?
item.description: A Full Refresh Sync will attempt to retrieve all data from the source every time a sync is run. Then there are two choices, Overwrite and Append.

item.title: What is Functional Data Engineering?
item.description: Functional Data Engineering bringsÂ clarity. When functions are “pure,” they do not have side effects. They can be written, tested, reasoned about, and debugged in isolation without understanding the external context or history of events surrounding their execution.

item.title: What is Functional Programming?
item.description: Functional Programming is a style of building functions that threaten computation as a mathematical function that avoids changing state and mutable data.

item.title: What is Granularity
item.description: Declaring theÂ granularity (or grain)Â is the pivotal step in Dimensional Modeling. The grainÂ establishes exactly what a single fact table row represents.

item.title: What is Idempotency?
item.description: Idempotency is the property of a particular operation that can be applied multiple times without changing the resulting outcome by being given the same inputs.

item.title: What is imperative?
item.description: AnÂ imperativeÂ pipeline tellsÂ howÂ to proceed at each step in a procedural manner. In contrast, aÂ declarativeÂ data pipeline does not tell the order it needs to be executed but instead allows each step/task to find the best time and way to run.

item.title: What is Incremental Synchronization?
item.description: Incremental synchronization is a process which efficiently copies data to a destination system by periodically executing queries on a source system for records that have been updated or inserted since the previous sync operation.

item.title: What is Key Performance Indicator (KPI)?
item.description: A performance indicator or key performance indicator (KPI) is a type of performance measurement. KPIs evaluate the success of an organization or of a particular activity (such as projects, programs, products, and other initiatives) in which it engages.

item.title: What is Kubernetes?
item.description: Itâ€™s a platform that allows you to run and orchestrate container workloads.Â KubernetesÂ has become the de-facto standardÂ for your cloud-native apps to (auto-)Â scale-outÂ and deploy your open-source zoo fast, cloud-provider-independent.

item.title: What is Machine Learning?
item.description: Machine learning (ML) is a type of artificial intelligence (AI) that allows software applications to become more accurate at predicting outcomes without being explicitly programmed to do so.

item.title: What is MapReduce?
item.description: MapReduce is a programming paradigm that enables massive scalability across hundreds or thousands of servers in a Hadoop cluster. As the processing component, MapReduce is the heart of Apache Hadoop.

item.title: What is Master Data Management (MDM)?
item.description: Master data management is a method to centralize master data. It’s the bridge between the business that maintain the data and know them best and the data folks, and it’s a tool of choice.

item.title: What is OLAP (Online Analytical Processing)?
item.description: OLAP is an acronym for Online Analytical Processing. OLAP performs multidimensional analysis of business data and provides the capability for complex calculations, trend analysis, and sophisticated data modeling.

item.title: What is OLTP (Online Transactional Processing)=
item.description: InÂ online transaction processingÂ (OLTP), information systems typically facilitate and manage transaction-oriented applications. It’s the opposite of OLAP (Online Analytical Processing).

item.title: What is ORC?
item.description: TheÂ Optimized Row ColumnarÂ (ORC)Â Data Lake File FormatÂ provides a highly efficient way to store Hive data. It was designed to overcome the limitations of the other Hive file formats.

item.title: What is Pandas?
item.description: Pandas is a software library written for the Python programming language for data manipulation and analysis. In particular, it offers data structures and operations for manipulating numerical tables and time series.

item.title: What is Python?
item.description: Python is a high-level, general-purpose programming language. Its design philosophy emphasizes code readability with the use of significant indentation. Python is dynamically-typed and garbage-collected.

item.title: What is Reverse ETL?
item.description: Reverse ETL is the flip side of the ETL/ ELT.Â With Reverse ETL, the data warehouse becomes the source rather than the destination.

item.title: What is Rust?
item.description: Former Mozilla employee Graydon Hoare initially createdÂ RustÂ as a personal project. The first stable release, Rust 1.0 was released on May 15, 2015.

item.title: What is Schema Evolution?
item.description: Automatic Schema Evolution is a crucial feature inÂ Data Lake Table Formats as changing formats is still a pain in today’s data engineer work.

item.title: What is semi-structured data?
item.description: Semi-structured data is data that lacks a rigid structure and that does not conform directly to a data model, but that has tags, metadata, or elements that describe the data.

item.title: What is Slowly Changing Dimension?
item.description: A Slowly Changing Dimension (SCD) isÂ a dimension that stores and manages both current and historical data over time in aÂ Data Warehouse.

item.title: What is SQL?
item.description: SQL isÂ a standardized language used to interact with relational [[databases]]. It stands for structured query language (SQL) and defines a standard programming language utilized to extract, organize, manage, and manipulate data stored in relational databases.

item.title: What is structured data?
item.description: Structured data refers to data that has been formatted into a well-defined schema. An example would be data that is stored with precisely defined columns in a relational database or excel spreadsheet.

item.title: What is the Data Engineering Lifecycle?
item.description: A data engineer today oversees the whole data engineering process, from collecting data from various sources to making it available for downstream processes.

item.title: What is the Modern Data Stack?
item.description: The Modern Data Stack (MDS) is a heap of open-source tools to achieve end-to-end analytics from ingestion to transformation to ML over to a columnar data warehouse or lake solution with an analytics BI dashboard backend.

item.title: What is the Open Data Stack?
item.description: The open data stack is a better term for the Modern Data Stack, but it also focuses on solutions built on open-source and open standards covering the Data Engineering Lifecycle.

item.title: What is Time Travel?
item.description: With time travel, theÂ Data Lake Table FormatÂ versions the big data you store in yourÂ Data Lake. You can access any historical version of that data, simplifying data management with easy-to-audit, rollback data in case of accidental bad writes or deletes, and reproduce experiments and reports.

item.title: What is unstructured data?
item.description: Unstructured data is data that does not conform to a data model and has no easily identifiable structure. Unstructured data cannot be easily used by programs, and is difficult to analyze.

item.title: What is YAML?
item.description: YAML is a data serialization language often used to write configuration files. Depending on whom you ask, YAML stands for yet another markup language, or YAML isnâ€™t markup language (a recursive acronym), which emphasizes that YAML is for data, not documents.
